We've reverted an update that prerendered AMP content, and it looks like Google is now able to pull through validation. You may want to trigger Validation inside of Google Search Console, which will enqueue a crawl. It may take several minutes to several hours for the validation to process since it has to go through Google's flow of scheduling and processing. However, you can also use <https://search.google.com/test/amp> on a per-URL basis to test out the affected pages and confirm that the enqueued recrawl should resolve the issue inside of GSC.

reminds me of an article I read recently where the author went on a mission to make the least accessible website that still passes Google’s accessibility audit with 100%. (he basically made the content invisible, keyboard input ignored, mouse input ignored) there was nothing you could do to read what was on the page unless you viewed source. I think he even had one with the source obfuscated.

I think we read the same article - it does a great job of making the point (that automated testing alone isn’t enough for accessibility). In case anyone’s interested I dug it up: <https://www.matuzo.at/blog/building-the-most-inaccessible-site-possible-with-a-perfect-lighthouse-score/>
yep that was it
